content.title: 'The Outer Worlds' Is The 'Fallout' Game We've All Been Waiting For - Forbes
content.desc: The Outer Worlds looks great. I imagine the developers at Obsidian have been watching the Fallout 76 with grim wonder and more than a little schadenfreude. After all, this is a studio who missed out on a bonus from publisher Bethesda because their game, Fallout: New Vegas, didn’t top 85 on Metacritic. Fallout 76 hasn’t even come close to that number. While New Vegas had its problems—Obsidian, like Bethesda, isn’t known for bug-free projects—it was an instant classic and a much-beloved entry into the franchise. Fallout 76 is a disaster. So it must have been rather serendipitous for Obsidian ...

content.title: Bethesda Responds To The 'Fallout 76' Support Glitch That Exposed Customer Data - Forbes
content.desc: Bethesda explains what happened in the support ticket fiasco. I’ve already written at length about the crazy glitch that allowed Fallout 76 players to accidentally gain access to other players’ personal information and support tickets. It was quite an astonishing technical error, even for Bethesda. Now the publisher has responded with a lengthy email sent out to the press yesterday afternoon. Here’s the full statement: As previously reported, onDecember 5, 2018, we experienced an error with our Customer Support website that resulted in the exposure of a limited number of customer support ti...

content.title: A 'Fallout 76' Support Ticket Glitch Gave Players Access To Everyone's Personal Information - Forbes
content.desc: In the most shocking twist yet, Fallout 76 players’ private information was just revealed to the whole world. In what may very well be the most bizarre and unsettling twist in the ongoing saga that is Fallout 76, players reported Wednesday that they inadvertently gained access to the support tickets of fellow Fallout 76 players. Not only did other gamers gain access to these tickets, they were able to see personal information such as addresses, phone numbers and credit card information. It gets weirder, of course—I’m not sure it could get any worse—because not only could players see this in...

content.title: Bethesda Is Sending 'Fallout 76' Power Armor Edition Customers Canvas Bags, After All - Forbes
content.desc: Power Armor Edition customers will get the bag at last. Bag-gate may soon draw to a close, as Fallout 76 publisher Bethesda is finally doing right by its customers. Following the launch of the game, super-fans who spent $200 on the special Power Armor Edition of the game discovered that instead of the nice canvas bag that was advertised when they pre-ordered, Bethesda had sent out cheap nylon bags instead. This revelation was made worse when Bethesda’s customer service responded in a less-than-helpful manner, sparking more outrage and frustration among players and some severe articles in th...

content.title: The 5 Biggest Problems With 'Fallout 76' - Forbes
content.desc: Fallout 76 is riddled with problems. Here are five of them. Well, I hate to tell you “I told you so.” But I told you so. When I wrote an article about Fallout 76 and how dubious I was that it would be a good game ready for a release in 2018, I received tons of backlash from angry fans. Now the game is rocking a 49/100 Metacritic score (on Xbox One, it’s slightly higher on PC and PS4) with a 2.7 user score. content.title: Making Good Use Of Your Time In The Elder Scrolls Online's New Free Trial Event - Forbes
content.desc: The ‘Elder Scrolls Online’ If you think you might enjoy the Elder Scrolls Online but haven’t been willing to buy the game, you can play for free for six days to find out if it’s your cup of tea. The free trial period begins on Thursday December 6 and runs through Tuesday the 11th on PC, Mac, Xbox One and PS4. Console players need an Xbox Live Gold or PlayStation Plus membership to take advantage of the free trial. content.title: Bethesda Gave 'Influencers' Nice 'Fallout 76' Canvas Bags Instead Of Fans Who Spent $200 - Forbes
content.desc: Fallout 76′s ‘bag-gate’ controversy deepens. In many ways, at least for those of us who comment on the video game industry’s many foibles, Fallout 76 is the gift that keeps on giving. Not so much, however, if you spent $200 on the game’s Power Armor Edition, thought you’d get a nice canvas bag, and were sent a cheap nylon bag instead. This on top of the game being a hot pile of steaming garbage, riddled with performance issues, bland combat and recycled assets. content.title: It's Hard To Imagine How 'Fallout 76' Ever Goes Free-To-Play - Forbes
content.desc: Fallout 76 Fans watched the price of Fallout 76 dip all the way down to around $35 just a week or two after launch around Black Friday sale time, and that combined with its myriad issues caused an old refrain to start up again. “Well, it’s only a matter of time until it goes free-to-play.” It’s the go-to for any struggling game when they realize it’s the best way to bulk up their playerbase, as they’ll hope to make money in other ways.
